title: 111_s1862
content: The Act titled "United States Secret Service Retirement Act of 2009" addresses the retirement treatment of certain Secret Service employees. The Act defines a "covered employee" as someone hired by the Secret Service between 1984-1986, with 10+ years of protection-related duties, currently serving in the Secret Service, and electing coverage. Not later than 60 days after the enactment of the Act, eligible individuals can elect to be covered employees under the District of Columbia Police and Firefighters Retirement and Disability System. The Office of Personnel Management and the Secret Service must notify eligible employees within 30 days. Retirement coverage conversion must be completed within 180 days of the Act's enactment. The Office of Personnel Management will prescribe regulations within 180 days of the Act's enactment for the transition of covered employees from the Federal Employees' Retirement System to the Civil Service Retirement System. Covered employees can elect coverage under subsection (b)(1) and be converted accordingly. The transition of covered employees from the Federal Employees' Retirement System to the Civil Service Retirement System will be regulated by the Office of Personnel Management. Covered employees in the District of Columbia will be covered under Chapter 7 of title 5 of the District of Columbia Code when they transition to the Civil Service Retirement System. The government of the District of Columbia will provide coverage for these employees. The District of Columbia Police and Firefighters Retirement and Disability System coverage for covered employees will be regulated under this Act. Covered employees who are members of the United States Secret Service Uniformed Division can transfer funds to the Civil Service Retirement and Disability Fund. The Act regulates the transfer of funds from covered employees of the United States Secret Service Uniformed Division to the general revenues of the District of Columbia. The salary of the member will be subject to deductions for credit to the District of Columbia's general revenues, and they will receive the same benefits as other members. The Act mandates that covered employees forfeit Thrift Savings Plan contributions and social security benefits upon conversion to the Civil Service Retirement System. The remaining amounts in the Thrift Savings Plan account can be transferred to a private account or the District of Columbia Police and Firefighter Retirement and Disability System. The covered employee shall forfeit contributions made for Social Security purposes based on their employment with the United States Secret Service. The forfeited funds will be retained in the Federal Old-Age and Survivors Insurance Trust Fund and the Federal Disability Insurance Trust Fund. The Commissioner of Social Security will adjust or remove any wage entries related to the forfeited funds. The covered employee forfeits contributions made for Social Security purposes based on their employment with the United States Secret Service. These forfeited funds are retained in the Federal Old-Age and Survivors Insurance Trust Fund and the Federal Disability Insurance Trust Fund. No individual is entitled to Social Security benefits based on these forfeited wages, and Medicare benefits are not affected by the forfeiture. The Act requires actions for implementation by various government agencies. It will take effect after 180 days from enactment, with exceptions for certain provisions. The Act will take effect after 180 days from enactment, with exceptions for certain provisions. Subsections (b) and (c)(1) and (3) shall take effect on the date of enactment of this Act.
